string_table.string: Use the w, a, s, and d keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.
To watch this video, use the preview feature in Storyline 360, upload your published output to a server, publish to Review 360, or switch to static video quality.
Streaming video is unavailable for local playback.

the main function of a key is printed the key itself. the second function is printed above the key to the left. it is accessed by pressing shift before pressing the key. the third function is printed above the key to the right. it is accessed by pressing alpha before the appropriate key. if the option is among a menu, it is selected by pressing the number key associated with it on the calculator screen. the main function of a key is printed the key itself. the second function is printed above the key to the left. it is accessed by pressing shift before pressing the key. the third function is printed above the key to the right. it is accessed by pressing alpha before the appropriate key. if the option is among a menu, it is selected by pressing the number key associated with it on the calculator screen. module 1: basics module 1: basics 1.1 order of operations 1.1 order of operations 1.1 order of operations 1.2 negative numbers 1.2 negative numbers 1.2 negative numbers 1.3 editing expressions 1.3 editing expressions 1.3 editing expressions the main function of a key is printed the key itself. the second function is printed above the key to the left. it is accessed by pressing shift before pressing the key. the third function is printed above the key to the right. it is accessed by pressing alpha before the appropriate key. if the option is among a menu, it is selected by pressing the number key associated with it on the calculator screen. watch video watch video more in this module jump to quiz jump to quiz jump to quiz

incorrect that is incorrect. please try again. try again try again try again try again try again try again incorrect try again! continue continue continue continue continue continue correct well done! continue continue continue continue continue continue try again! write parentheses ( ) in this statement to make it correct. 3 + 4 5 + 6 = 47 module 1: basics 1.1 order of operations module 1: basics 1.1 order of operations practice! practice! submit 1.1 order of operations 1.1 order of operations 1.2 negative numbers 1.2 negative numbers 1.2 negative numbers 1.3 editing expressions 1.3 editing expressions 1.3 editing expressions more in this module jump to quiz jump to quiz jump to quiz calculators use normal conventions for evaluating mathematical expressions; (pemdas) parenthesis, exponents, multiplication, division, addition, subtraction for example 3 + 4 5 should result in 23, getting 35 means youre using a business calculator or an old model. get rid of it! but what if you want to calculate (3 + 4)5? either insert 3 + 4 = to get 7, and then 5 = to get 35. or use parenthesis ( ). (3 + 4) 5 the calculator can handle any level of parentheses tossed at it. back to basics back to basics back to basics

incorrect try again! try again try again try again try again try again try again incorrect try again! continue continue continue continue continue continue correct well done! continue continue continue continue continue continue if you want to insert a negative number standing by itself, clear out the previous calculation by pressing on/c. otherwise, when you press the negative sign key, the calculator assumes you want to take the previous result (if any) as the starting point for the second calculation. module 1: basics 1.2 negative numbers module 1: basics 1.2 negative numbers calculate 6 + 4, then separately, calculate -2 + 6 and give the answer. practice! practice! submit back to basics back to basics back to basics 1.2 negative numbers 1.2 negative numbers 1.3 editing expressions 1.3 editing expressions 1.3 editing expressions more in this module jump to quiz jump to quiz jump to quiz 1.1 order of operations 1.1 order of operations 1.1 order of operations

module 1: basics 1.3 editing expressions module 1: basics 1.3 editing expressions insert 3 + 4 5 = to your calculator, then replace the + sign with - . practice! practice! back to basics back to basics back to basics 1.3 editing expressions 1.3 editing expressions more in this module jump to quiz jump to quiz jump to quiz 1.1 order of operations 1.1 order of operations 1.1 order of operations 1.2 negative numbers 1.2 negative numbers 1.2 negative numbers what if you make a mistake while inserting your expression? one way out is to press ac and re-do the expression from the beginning. another way is to use the left and right arrow keys and del key.

your calculator perform straightforward functions located on the black keys such as: squares, square roots, arbitrary powers, and functions with shift key if located above the black keys such as: cubes, cube roots, arbitrary roots your calculator perform straightforward functions located on the black keys such as: squares, square roots, arbitrary powers, and functions with shift key if located above the black keys such as: cubes, cube roots, arbitrary roots your calculator perform straightforward functions located on the black keys such as: squares, square roots, arbitrary powers, and functions with shift key if located above the black keys such as: cubes, cube roots, arbitrary roots your calculator perform straightforward functions located on the black keys such as: squares, square roots, arbitrary powers, and functions with shift key if located above the black keys such as: cubes, cube roots, arbitrary roots your calculator perform straightforward functions located on the black keys such as: squares, cubes, square roots, arbitrary powers, and functions with shift key if located above the black keys such as: cube roots, arbitrary roots your calculator perform straightforward functions located on the black keys such as: squares, square roots, arbitrary powers, and functions with shift key if located above the black keys such as: cubes, cube roots, arbitrary roots your calculator perform straightforward functions located on the black keys such as: squares, square roots, arbitrary powers, and functions with shift key if located above the black keys such as: cubes, cube roots, arbitrary roots module 2: powers and roots module 2: powers and roots 2.1 compound interest 2.1 compound interest 2.1 compound interest watch video watch video more in this module jump to quiz jump to quiz jump to quiz remember even roots takes two values; use memory locations in order no to insert in the same data value more than once and copying down intermediate results on paper to avoid the risk of inserting, copying down, or re-entering incorrect values. use memory locations, namely a, b, c, d, e, f, m, x, and y, to: store values: sto, followed by the key with the name of the memory location recall values: shift rcl followed by the memory location the values stored in the memory locations remain unchanged when pressing ac, or even when turning the calculator off. clear all memory location by pressing shift rcl. use memory locations in order no to insert in the same data value more than once and copying down intermediate results on paper to avoid the risk of inserting, copying down, or re-entering incorrect values. use memory locations, namely a, b, c, d, e, f, m, x, and y, to: store values: sto, followed by the key with the name of the memory location recall values: shift rcl followed by the memory location the values stored in the memory locations remain unchanged when pressing ac, or even when turning the calculator off. clear all memory location by pressing shift rcl. use memory locations in order no to insert locations remain unchanged when pressing ac, or even when turning the calculator off. clear all memory location by pressing shift rcl. use memory locations in order not to insert in the same data unchanged when pressing ac, or even when turning the calculator off. clear all memory location by pressing shift rcl. module 3: memory locations module 3: memory locations 3.1 solving quadratic incorrect try again! try again try again try again try again try again try again incorrect try again! continue continue continue continue continue continue correct well done! continue continue continue continue continue continue back to memory locations back to memory locations back to memory locations module 3: memory locations 3.1 solving quadratic equations module 3: memory locations 3.1 solving quadratic equations solve submit using the quadratic formula. give the values of x separated by a comma. jump to quiz jump to quiz jump to quiz remember remember using memory locations for the coefficients makes the job easier. to solve the quadratic equation practice practice

when your work includes angels, you must ensure that your calculator is using the correct system of angle measurement- degrees or radians. some of the functions that locate on the same key are inverses of each other undo each other. examples of these are sin, cos, and tan keys which have their inverse trig functions locate above the same keys. module 4: angles module 4: angles 4.1 converting between deg. & rad. 4.1 converting between deg. & rad. 4.1 converting between deg. & rad. 4.2 right triangles 4.2 right triangles 4.2 right triangles 4.3 law of cosine 4.3 law of cosine 4.3 law of cosine when your work includes angels, you must ensure that your calculator is using the correct system of angle measurement- degrees or radians. some of the functions that locate on the same key are inverses of each other undo each other. examples of these are sin, cos, and tan keys which have their inverse trig functions locate above the same keys. more in this module jump to quiz jump to quiz jump to quiz

incorrect try again! try again try again try again try again try again try again incorrect try again! continue continue continue continue continue continue correct well done! continue continue continue continue continue continue if abc is a right triangle, with right angle at c, then: module 4: angles 4.2 right triangles module 4: angles 4.2 right triangles back to angles back to angles back to angles a group of hikers leave point p, which is on a road that runs northsouth, and walk for 6 hours in the direction n20e to reach point q. they walk at 5 km/h. what is the shortest distance x from q back to the road? give your answer correct to 1 decimal place? submit jump to quiz jump to quiz jump to quiz 4.1 converting between deg. & rad. 4.1 converting between deg. & rad. 4.1 converting between deg. & rad. 4.2 right triangles 4.2 right triangles 4.3 law of cosine 4.3 law of cosine 4.3 law of cosine more in this module remember remember practice practice

incorrect try again! try again try again try again try again try again try again incorrect try again! continue continue continue continue continue continue correct well done! continue continue continue continue continue continue module 4: angles 4.1 convert between degrees and radians module 4: angles 4.1 convert between degrees and radians you can always multiply by /180 or 180/ to convert between degrees and radians. or let your calculator make the conversion for you by selecting the appropriate choice under mode or menu. back to angles back to angles back to angles jump to quiz jump to quiz jump to quiz 4.1 converting between deg. & rad. 4.1 converting between deg. & rad. 4.2 right triangles 4.2 right triangles 4.2 right triangles 4.3 law of cosine 4.3 law of cosine 4.3 law of cosine more in this module convert 11/6 radians into degrees? submit practice practice

incorrect try again! try again try again try again try again try again try again incorrect try again! continue continue continue continue continue continue correct well done! continue continue continue continue continue continue for the triangle abc, the law of cosine is: module 4: angles 4.3 law of cosine module 4: angles 4.3 law of cosine back to angles back to angles back to angles a b c the emblem, shown below, consists of a triangle abc joined to a sector cbd of a circle with radius 4 cm and centre b. the points a, b and d lie on a straight line with ab = 5 cm and bd = 4 cm. angle bac = 0.6 radians and ac is the longest side of the triangle abc. use the low of cosine to find the measurement of that angle abc, correct to 3 significant figures. submit jump to quiz jump to quiz jump to quiz 4.1 converting between deg. & rad. 4.1 converting between deg. & rad. 4.1 converting between deg. & rad. 4.2 right triangles 4.2 right triangles 4.2 right triangles 4.3 law of cosine 4.3 law of cosine more in this module remember remember practice practice

keep in mind the regulations and restrictions regarding calculator use by the examination board. igcse act ib tips tips grab your calculator! a scientific calculator on hand allows learners to practice the skills alongside the instructional materials. a physical calculator can solidify practical application. course stage 1 does not encompass all the features of a scientific calculator. besides, it is tailored for a typical scientific calculator. if you're using a different model, please utilize the corresponding features on your own calculator. you may need to refer to your calculator's manual. various brands and models of calculators are available; select the one that best fits your needs. check here! sat tawjihi

welcome to the mastering scientific calculator techniques self-learning course for middle and high schoolers preparing for mathematics examinations. this course aims to equip the learners with the essential skills required to enhance exam readiness via hands-on exercises at their own pace. mastering such techniques boosts confidence and reduces exam anxiety. instead of crunching numbers, the examinee will have more time to focus on more profound concepts, thus enhancing the opportunity to eliminate the worry of careless mistakes and ensure accurate results. whether for your igcse, act, ib, tawjihi, or other math exam, this course has something for you. get ready to unlock your calculator's potential and approach your exams with confidence and clarity. happy learning! welcome message welcome message

objectives objectives by the end of this course learners are expected to: develop proficiency in using various calculator functions effectively and efficiently. master hierarchy of arithmetic operations, dealing with given data, and use storage and other calculator features to solve problems. demonstrate appropriate using of calculators in different mathematical contexts.
